docs.lead_paragraph: At a growing number of rehabilitation centers, stroke patients move around with their limbs tightly bandaged, mummy style. Toddlers with cerebral palsy are ensconced in partial body casts. Paraplegics are slung in harnesses and made to walk on treadmills, with automatic equipment moving their feet. Even the blind are having their brains reconfigured with a special camera that allows them ''see'' via a device worn on the tongue. Rehabilitation may never look the same. Like engineers in thrall to a new idea, many of the doctors and therapists who help patients with brain injuries are using revolutionary insights about the brain to coax the nervous system into rewiring itself.

headline.main: Therapies Push Injured Brains and Spinal Cords Into New Paths

docs.lead_paragraph: Pumps that are used to keep hearts alive while a patient waits for a transplant appear to allow the body a chance to repair some damage long thought to be irreversible, a study published last week in the journal Circulation has found. The researchers, from the Cleveland Clinic, noted that some doctors had seen such striking improvements in patients after they received the pump, known as a left ventricular assist device, or LVAD (pronounced EL-vad), that they wondered whether the transplant had been necessary.

headline.main: Heart Pumps May Have Extra Benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Helene Gayle began her career at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta in 1984, there was no AIDS division or office devoted to preventing the disease. No one knew for sure how it was caused or transmitted or even what to call it, much less how to stop it. But 14 years into the epidemic, when the National Center for H.I.V., S.T.D. and TB Prevention was belatedly created, Dr. Gayle was chosen to run it. Today the office has a staff of 1,400 and an annual budget of $1 billion.

headline.main: A Charge to Take AIDS Messages From a National to a Global Scale

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of a supplement commonly used for children with attention deficit disorder found that it did not decrease the condition's symptoms. The study, published this month in The Journal of Pediatrics, looked at docosahexaenoic acid, known as DHA. Many parents of children with attention deficit disorder have turned to alternative medicine in place of, or in addition to, prescription stimulants like Ritalin. DHA has been a popular supplement since several studies suggested that children with attention disorders had low levels of DHA, a fatty acid that plays a role in neuronal development.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alfalfa sprouts caused more widespread outbreaks of food poisoning in California from 1996 to 1998 than anything else, according to a new study conducted by the State Department of Health Services. The study, published last week in The Annals of Internal Medicine, found that more than half of the outbreaks involving more than one county were linked to sprouts (tainted meat or eggs tend to cause more localized outbreaks). Two people died and an estimated 22,000 people were infected with salmonella or E. coli O157, the bacteria responsible for most serious cases of food poisoning, the study said.

headline.main: Tainted Track Record of Alfalfa Sprouts
